hook.text: Queen Elizabeth I wore a collar so enormous she couldn't turn her head. That was the point.

buildup.text: The ruff was a stiffened lace collar that fanned out like a platter around the neck.

discovery.text: Ruffs required starchâ€”a new inventionâ€”and heated poking sticks to shape each pleat by hand.

twist.text: Ruffs grew so absurdly wide that special long spoons were invented just so people could eat.

climax.text: The bigger your ruff, the less you could do. That was the status signal: you didn't need to work.

punchline.text: Impracticality was the ultimate power flex.

quiz.question: Why did Elizabethan ruffs grow to extreme sizes?
options: Starch technology made smaller ruffs impossible
Larger ruffs provided better neck protection
They signaled high status by showing the wearer didn't need to work
